articles.headline: Fliers Fed Up? Airline Employees Feel the Same
articles.snippet: A rich record of employee discontent emerges from question-and-answer sessions at US Airways.
articles.abstract: A rich record of employee discontent emerges from question-and-answer sessions at US Airways.
articles.lead_paragraph: And you thought the passengers were mad.

articles.headline: Emerald City of Giving Does Exist
articles.snippet: When it comes to corporate philanthropy, Minneapolis-St. Paul is a bastion of giving in an age when most companies are cutting back.
articles.abstract: When it comes to corporate philanthropy, Minneapolis-St. Paul is a bastion of giving in an age when most companies are cutting back.
articles.lead_paragraph: My philanthropic tour of Minneapolis began on the banks of the Mississippi River, where the Great Northern Railroad once transported flour from the giant mills of General Mills and Pillsbury. The Great Northern is long gone  merged into the Burlington Northern almost 40 years ago, and though the mills are still standing, they have long since been converted to other uses, as General Mills moved to the suburbs, and, in time, acquired its rival Pillsbury.

articles.headline: For Pet Owners, Too, Toys a Reason for Concern
articles.snippet: Following the pet food scare this year, and a spate of children’s toy recalls, pet owners have been stepping forward to ask: How safe are pet toys?
articles.abstract: Following the pet food scare this year, and a spate of children’s toy recalls, pet owners have been stepping forward to ask: How safe are pet toys?
articles.lead_paragraph: When Lane Nemeth, who founded Discovery Toys in 1978 and sold the company to Avon two decades later, decided to start a pet products company a few years ago, one of the first things she did was to look for regulations about how to manufacture pet toys safely.

articles.headline: Charming and Aloof, Huckabee Changed State
articles.snippet: Mike Huckabee produced a legacy in Arkansas like few other Republican governors in the South, but he tended to freeze out anyone who disagreed with his plans.
articles.abstract: Mike Huckabee produced a legacy in Arkansas like few other Republican governors in the South, but he tended to freeze out anyone who disagreed with his plans.
articles.lead_paragraph: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.  In more than a decade of presiding over this state, Mike Huckabee produced a legacy like few other Republican governors in the South, surprising even liberal Democrats with his willingness to upend some of Arkansas’s more parochial traditions.
articles.byline: By Adam Nossiter and David Barstow

articles.headline: News Mixed, but Stocks Still Manage Strong Rally
articles.snippet: Stock markets ended the week with a surge on reports of a possible foreign investment in Merrill Lynch and an uptick in consumer spending.
articles.abstract: Stock markets ended the week with a surge on reports of a possible foreign investment in Merrill Lynch and an uptick in consumer spending.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stock markets surged Friday on reports of a possible foreign investment in Merrill Lynch and an uptick in consumer spending.

articles.headline: No Joke, Bulb Change Is Challenge for U.S.
articles.snippet: When 2012 hits, stores will no longer be able to sell the cheap but inefficient incandescent light bulbs that are fixtures in most homes.
articles.abstract: When 2012 hits, stores will no longer be able to sell the cheap but inefficient incandescent light bulbs that are fixtures in most homes.
articles.lead_paragraph: The new energy bill signed this week makes it official. When 2012 hits, stores can no longer sell the cheap but inefficient incandescent light bulbs that are fixtures in most homes.

articles.headline: The Recalls’ Aftershocks
articles.snippet: What happened to all the lead-tainted products that have been recalled recently? Most, it turns out, may still be in consumers’ hands.
articles.abstract: What happened to all the lead-tainted products that have been recalled recently? Most, it turns out, may still be in consumers’ hands.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wondering what happened to all the lead-tainted products that have been recalled recently?
articles.byline: By Louise Story and David Barboza

articles.headline: Big Fund to Prop Up Securities Is Scrapped
articles.snippet: Big banks have pulled the plug on a Treasury Department-backed plan to rescue troubled investment vehicles leveled by the subprime mortgage crisis.
articles.abstract: Big banks have pulled the plug on a Treasury Department-backed plan to rescue troubled investment vehicles leveled by the subprime mortgage crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some of the country’s biggest banks have pulled the plug on a plan backed by the Treasury Department to rescue troubled investment vehicles that were leveled by the subprime mortgage crisis.

articles.headline: Christmas Flourishes, in a Trim Green Stillness
articles.snippet: Around the country, this is the season when cemeteries become homes for many families’ second Christmas tree.
articles.abstract: Around the country, this is the season when cemeteries become homes for many families’ second Christmas tree.
articles.lead_paragraph: CULVER CITY, Calif.  Around the country, this is the season when cemeteries become homes for many families’ second Christmas tree, where devotion meets tinsel, “Let It Snow” garden ornaments and the occasional Santa swizzle stick.

articles.headline: Porsche and VW: One Happy Family?
articles.snippet: The Beetle and 911 Turbo in one garage:  What seems a mismatch is really the closing of the circle for a dynasty.
articles.abstract: The Beetle and 911 Turbo in one garage:  What seems a mismatch is really the closing of the circle for a dynasty.
articles.lead_paragraph: STUTTGART, Germany

articles.headline: Two Candidates, Two Fortunes, Two Distinct Views of Wealth
articles.snippet: John Edwards and Mitt Romney are basing their candidacies in large measure on the very different lessons each has taken from his own success.
articles.abstract: John Edwards and Mitt Romney are basing their candidacies in large measure on the very different lessons each has taken from his own success.
articles.lead_paragraph: By the final weeks of 1984, well before either turned 40, John Edwards and Mitt Romney had already built successful careers. But the two men were each on the verge of an entirely new level of financial success.

articles.headline: This Is the Sound of a Bubble Bursting
articles.snippet: As real estate values fall, local governments from Virginia to California are cutting services and shelving projects.
articles.abstract: As real estate values fall, local governments from Virginia to California are cutting services and shelving projects.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cape Coral, Fla.

articles.headline: In a Force for Iraqi Calm, Seeds of Conflict
articles.snippet: Sunni “Awakening” groups, paid by the U.S. to fight extremists, have become a success story, but there are concerns about what will happen to them after a handoff.
articles.abstract: Sunni “Awakening” groups, paid by the U.S. to fight extremists, have become a success story, but there are concerns about what will happen to them after a handoff.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  The thin teenage boy rushed up to the patrol of American soldiers walking through Dora, a shrapnel-scarred neighborhood of the capital, and lifted his shirt to show them a mass of red welts across his back.
articles.byline: By Alissa J. Rubin and Damien Cave

articles.headline: Taxes Are Reassessed in Housing Slump
articles.snippet: Downward assessments appear most pronounced in areas where the market was exploding just a few years ago, or where economic conditions are poorest.
articles.abstract: Downward assessments appear most pronounced in areas where the market was exploding just a few years ago, or where economic conditions are poorest.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Home owners across the nation are looking to county governments to reassess the values of their homes in the face of flattening and falling prices that have befallen scores of markets. Downward assessments, done at the request of homeowners or pre-emptively by government, appear to be most pronounced in areas where the housing market was exploding just a few years ago, or where economic conditions are poorest.

articles.headline: Where Boys Were Kings, a Shift Toward Baby Girls
articles.snippet: A centuries-old South Korean preference for boys is fading.
articles.abstract: A centuries-old South Korean preference for boys is fading.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea  When Park He-ran was a young mother, other women would approach her to ask what her secret was. She had given birth to three boys in a row at a time when South Korean women considered it their paramount duty to bear a son.

articles.headline: Democrats Make Bush School Act an Election Issue
articles.snippet: Criticism of the No Child Left Behind Act is endangering its renewal.
articles.abstract: Criticism of the No Child Left Behind Act is endangering its renewal.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Teachers cheered Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton when she stepped before them last month at an elementary school in Waterloo, Iowa, and said she would “end” the No Child Left Behind Act because it was “just not working.”

articles.headline: Clicking the Way to Mortgage Savings
articles.snippet: A new Web site helps consumers protect themselves from excessive fees that can drive up the price of a home.
articles.abstract: A new Web site helps consumers protect themselves from excessive fees that can drive up the price of a home.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAST week, the Federal Reserve got around to tightening mortgage lending standards, hoping to eliminate some of the practices that have made borrowing to buy a home so confounding and costly. Many of the Fed’s changes make sense, especially those that require hidden broker fees to be clearly disclosed and prepayment fees to disappear before a huge rate reset occurs.

articles.headline: Shielding Money Clashes With Elders’ Free Will
articles.snippet: Elderly plaintiffs have sued companies for financial abuse even though they admit they made unwise decisions.
articles.abstract: Elderly plaintiffs have sued companies for financial abuse even though they admit they made unwise decisions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Eight years ago, when Robert J. Pyle was 73 years old, he had about $500,000 in the bank and owned a house in Northern California worth about $650,000. He was looking forward to a comfortable retirement.

articles.headline: What Would Henry Luce Do? Looking Forward at Time Warner
articles.snippet: Though Jeffrey L. Bewkes will take over as Time Warner’s chief executive at the beginning of January, it remains unclear how the company will look after he takes control.
articles.abstract: Though Jeffrey L. Bewkes will take over as Time Warner’s chief executive at the beginning of January, it remains unclear how the company will look after he takes control.
articles.lead_paragraph: For someone with a reputation for being unsentimental about his company, it was perhaps surprising that Jeffrey L. Bewkes looked to the past when he spoke at a Time Warner management retreat in Miami in late November  his first since being tapped as the company’s next chief executive.

articles.headline: Anarchists in the Aisles? Stores Provide a Stage
articles.snippet: Shopdropping is the practice by anti-consumerist artists of leaving fake products with political messages on shelves.
articles.abstract: Shopdropping is the practice by anti-consumerist artists of leaving fake products with political messages on shelves.
articles.lead_paragraph: This is the season of frenetic shopping, but for a devious few people it’s also the season of spirited shopdropping.

articles.headline: How the Cooling Economy Is Stealing Target’s Christmas
articles.snippet: Despite rosier expectations, Target is muddling through this holiday season, perplexing those who consider the chain a bellwether.
articles.abstract: Despite rosier expectations, Target is muddling through this holiday season, perplexing those who consider the chain a bellwether.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was supposed to be a Target Christmas.

articles.headline: In Kentucky’s Teeth, Toll of Poverty and Neglect
articles.snippet: About half the population in Kentucky does not have dental insurance, and 1 in 10 are missing all their teeth.
articles.abstract: About half the population in Kentucky does not have dental insurance, and 1 in 10 are missing all their teeth.
articles.lead_paragraph: BARBOURVILLE, Ky.  In the 18 years he has been visiting nursing homes, seeing patients in his private practice and, more recently, driving his mobile dental clinic through Appalachian hills and hollows, Dr. Edwin E. Smith has seen the extremes of neglect.

articles.headline: Giuliani Hits a Rocky Stretch as Voting Approaches
articles.snippet: Rudolph W. Giuliani’s presidential campaign has been hurt by acknowledged missteps, sharp shifts in strategy and reports about his personal life.
articles.abstract: Rudolph W. Giuliani’s presidential campaign has been hurt by acknowledged missteps, sharp shifts in strategy and reports about his personal life.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAMPTON, N.H.  Rudolph W. Giuliani has entered a turbulent period in his campaign for the Republican presidential nomination, marked by what his aides acknowledge are missteps, sharp shifts in strategy and evidence that reports about his personal life have hurt his national standing.

articles.headline: Oprah Puts Her Brand on the Line
articles.snippet: What works for Oprah the inspiring talk-show host  may not work for Oprah the political player. After her endorsement of Barack Obama, part of her base was livid.
articles.abstract: What works for Oprah the inspiring talk-show host  may not work for Oprah the political player. After her endorsement of Barack Obama, part of her base was livid.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last week, Denzel Washington and Harvey Weinstein were hosts for the New York premiere of “The Great Debaters” at the Ziegfeld Theater in Manhattan. Set to go into wide release on Christmas Day, “The Great Debaters” traces the mostly true story of the debate team of tiny Wiley College. It was led by a charismatic professor named Melvin B. Tolson, played by Mr. Washington, who also directed the film.

articles.headline: The Top Player in This League? It May Be the Sports Reporter
articles.snippet: Rising demand for star sportswriters, driven by rising television and Internet revenue, is leading to intense competition to hire talent.
articles.abstract: Rising demand for star sportswriters, driven by rising television and Internet revenue, is leading to intense competition to hire talent.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few teams are rich and getting richer, hunting more avidly than ever for talent, raiding the less-endowed leagues, poaching free agents and bidding the prices of star players to unheard-of heights.

articles.headline: U.S. Officials See Waste in Billions Sent to Pakistan
articles.snippet: Money intended to bolster Pakistan’s military effort against Al Qaeda and the Taliban has been diverted toward weapons systems to counter India, officials said.
articles.abstract: Money intended to bolster Pakistan’s military effort against Al Qaeda and the Taliban has been diverted toward weapons systems to counter India, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  After the United States has spent more than $5 billion in a largely failed effort to bolster the Pakistani military effort against Al Qaeda and the Taliban, some American officials now acknowledge that there were too few controls over the money. The strategy to improve the Pakistani military, they said, needs to be completely revamped.
articles.byline: By David Rohde, Carlotta Gall, Eric Schmitt and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: E-Greetings Gain Ground at Businesses This Season
articles.snippet: Once seen as the tacky, last-minute substitute for pen and paper, e-cards have become more acceptable this holiday season.
articles.abstract: Once seen as the tacky, last-minute substitute for pen and paper, e-cards have become more acceptable this holiday season.
articles.lead_paragraph: Have you sent out your holiday cards this year? What about your e-cards?
